title: Frederick Douglass National Historic Site: Frederick Douglass's Bible
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     Collections     Frederick Douglass's Bible                Frederick Douglass's Bible         Washington, D.C.'s Metropolitan A.M.E. Church gave this Bible to Frederick Douglass in 1889. NPS  Frederick Douglass received this Holy Bible from members of the Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church in Washington, D.C. Embossed with his name on the front cover, this handsome, leather-bound edition was published by Oxford University Press and contains both the Old and New Testaments. The congregation presented it to Douglass on September 1, 1889, as he prepared to travel to Haiti, where he had been appointed by President Benjamin Harrison to serve as U.S. Minister and Consul General. According to the Washington Evening Star, "Mr. Douglass warmly and eloquently thanked the donors for their kindness."  The Bible is part of the museum collections at the Frederick Douglass National Historic Site. Attorney General Loretta Lynch used this Bible to take her oath of office on June 17, 2015.
